I guess what makes Amar's conclusion so odd is that it actually so much more applicable to the other side. Â If the ACA is upheld, how many elections are five liberal justices allowed to undo? (Yes, yes, I know. Repeal of the is still possible by legislative means even if the ACA is upheld. But as a practical matter that requires conservatives control of both houses of congress and the white house early enough for it to be practical. It's a very narrow window. And in other circumstances you might say, well, that's the way the cookie crumbles. But given that the ACA was passed in such dubious circumstances (via reconciliation, etc.) that's Cold Comfort.)
Isn't that a political problem, and not a Constitutional problem? If the mandate is upheld, it will be on the backs of Wickard, Lopez, Raich, and Morrison. If it's struck down, it will be in the wake of the 2010 elections, and on the basis of an argument that conjures up nightmares, drawn from arbitrary distinctions in regulatory analysisÂ never before seen.
